Award.AwardTitle: Joint Influences on Perceived Vulnerability and Behavior

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
People routinely encounter situations in which they must decide how to respond to a potential danger or health threat (e.g., tornado siren, flu virus, undercooked food, asbestos, sports injury, a dark alley, cigarette smoke, sun exposure, an icy road, a pit bull). A person?s response to a danger or threat should depend on, among other things, the likelihood of harm. For example, a person would be foolish to stop or avoid a desired activity because of a negligible likelihood of harm, yet would be ill-advised to continue with an activity associated with a high likelihood of serious harm. Consequently, it is crucial to understand what shapes people?s perceptions of vulnerability (i.e., subjective likelihood of harm from a threat) and how these perceptions influence behavior.

This is a complex challenge because for any given threat, there is a variety of information that could influence perceived vulnerability. To illustrate, consider a person who is about to walk on a forest trail and is thinking about the threat of mosquitoes carrying West Nile Virus. Perceived vulnerability to West Nile might be affected by knowledge of the frequencies of getting bites on past walks, the extent to which the trail seems representative of the type that attracts mosquitoes, a newspaper story about the rates of West Nile Virus, and whether other hikers seem to be concerned about the virus.

A key goal for this project is to refine and test a new theory of how various factors jointly shape perceptions of vulnerability and behavior. Unlike existing theories, this one is explicit in representing six factors that drive vulnerability and also makes an important distinction between people?s explicit reports of judged likelihood and the perceptions of vulnerability that drive behavior. An interrelated second goal of the project is to develop a flexible computer-based paradigm that can be used by a broad array of researchers for experimentally testing how various jointly operating factors influence decisions and behavior in the presence of a potential threat.

The theory and empirical findings from this project should have important implications across fields concerned with subjective threat assessment and/or decision making under uncertainty. This includes fields like health psychology, occupational safety/injury prevention, and decision making. The studies should also provide insight about how to best measure people?s perceived vulnerability to health risks, as well as how to design public?health interventions aimed at making people aware of their vulnerability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on establishing a better understanding of people's decision making in response to potential safety hazards, especially when they have various sources of information about their vulnerability to the hazards. More broadly, we explored how various factors jointly shape optimism, perceptions of vulnerability, and behavior.  One specific objective for the project was to develop a flexible computer-based task that could be used by a broad array of researchers for experimentally testing behavior under risk and uncertainty.  We developed three versions of a modifiable task called DART (Decisions About Risk Task) that researchers can use to present people with an abstract representation of everyday situations in which they must use acquired knowledge of potential threats to make good decisions.  The flexibility of DART is a unique feature; it offers a wide range of options for controlling and modifying what people learn regarding the probability of a potential hazard to cause harm.  Therefore, DART provides a new tool for researchers studying how people learn about and use information about risk. A DART website was created, making downloads of all three versions and supporting information accessible to anyone, including educators who can use the task for demonstrations or student-led research.  One of the versions of DART requires no special programming skills for modification and use.

 

Several lines of research were conducted, some using the DART and others using different paradigms.  One theme in the findings is that measurement choices can have a significant influence on key conclusions. That is, conclusions about the causal impact of various factors on judgments (factors such as social comparisons, outcome desirability, and summarized numeric information) may be quite distinct depending on what measures were used to assess those judgments.  Optimism and perceived vulnerability are not detected in an interchangeable way by measures of behavioral choices, numeric likelihoods, and verbal likelihoods.  Another theme in our findings across several lines of research is that people’s beliefs and behaviors are influenced by comparative considerations, even when these may seem objectively irrelevant.  The idea that relative considerations matter is not novel in itself, but the particular instances we studied provide important new examples of this phenomenon.  The research has implications for how health communicators and policy experts attempt to reduce risky behavior and encourage healthy decision making in society.  For example, our research suggests that descriptions of concern about one potential hazard can reduce safe decision making about a related hazard. As such, experts attempting to inform people about a new risk may be advised to remind people of related risks that remain important.  Also, our research on radon risk revealed that health messages should not be aimed at one group without considering the implications for other groups.  Constructing public messages that primarily focus on those who are at the most risk for a particular hazard can, unfortunately, reduce the perceived vulnerability of others who are at intermediate levels of risk. 

 

Finally, this project supported the education of undergraduate and graduate students.  Twenty-four undergraduate psychology majors gained research experience associated with the project. Two new courses on judgment and decision making were created, one each at the undergraduate and graduate levels.  Seven graduate students were involved as collaborators on aspects of the research. Four of the seven now have their PhDs and secured tenure-track or postdoctoral positions.  Six honors projects were completed by students in our lab; four of the honors students advanced to PhD programs in psychology and a fifth is pursuing a Master’s Degree in public health.  Outreach presentations were given to high school and community college classes.
